justifications: Obama told NPR he respects the will of British voters and now anticipates no "major cataclysmic changes as a consequence of this"
Obama told NPR on Tuesday concerning the Brexit vote. "I think that the best way to think about this is: a pause button has been pressed on the project of full European integration."
Obama also said, "There is been a little bit of hysteria post-Brexit vote, as if somehow NATO's gone."
Obama also said, "There is been a little bit of hysteria post-Brexit vote, as if somehow... the trans-Atlantic alliance is dissolving."
Obama said in April... "It could be five years from now, 10 years from now before we are actually able to get something done..."

"I do not anticipate that anything I have said will change the position of those who are leading the campaigns in one direction or the other, but for ordinary voters I thought it would be relevant to hear what the president of the United States, who loves the British people and cares deeply about this relationship, has to say."

references: free trade pact with a post-EU United Kingdom

justifications: Obama decided it would be a good idea to threaten ordinary British people with the possibility that the United States could wait an entire decade to establish a free trade pact with a post-EU United Kingdom.
Obama told NPR he respects the will of British voters.

Obama also took a trade-related swipe at presumed 2016 Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump in the NPR interview. "Mr. Trump embodies global elites and has taken full advantage of it his entire life."
"Keep in mind that Norway is not a member of the European Union, but Norway is one of our closest allies..."
"They align themselves on almost every issue with Europe and us. They are a place that is continually supporting the kinds of initiatives internationally that we support."
On June 23, 51.9 percent of British citizens voted to leave the European Union.
